TopicTitle: Nodes close together on thin parts...

Articles.Content:
Anyone have tips or hints for dealing with thin stack-attach parts? It's a hassle to attach them in game, as if you don't orient the camera just right in the VAB, the bottom node tries to attach instead of the top one and your part winds up completely inside the part you're trying to attach to, which depending on collider design, can make it hard to grab it and try again without throwing the whole part above yours in the trash and reattaching both...

I could, of course, offset one or both nodes from the centerline of the rocket, but this would limit the player's ability to rotate the parts if they had a reason to... and might make any rocket wobble asymmetrical, which isn't good.

I know that with plugins I could disable the bottom node until the top one is attached, or require a right click to show the bottom node, or some other clever solution like that... but... the parts pack I'm working on doesn't currently have any plugin dependencies and I'd love to keep it that way.

It's not totally useless without doing anything, but if there's an easy fix I'm just ignoring, I thought it was at least worth asking!
I don't think you can do anything to the nodes themselves. I thought node orientation can take care of that but now that I think about it even stock docking ports behave the way you described.
Yeah, node's snap 180 degrees from the correct orientation just as easily as they do at the right orientation. I don't know if that's an intentional behavior or a bug that hasn't been squashed...
Given that it's causing obvious problems I'd say it's a bug. You should report it.

A point of observation is that larger nodes are also more "sticky" in this regard. It looks like the node spheres are a pretty good indication of the radius they need to come into, in order to snap into place. If the spheres overlap, then placement becomes more difficult.

So as a general rule, I try not to get ultra-thin with my parts.

But yes, that would be a great suggestion of but report. Since the node data in the CFGs contain orientation information, the VAB could prioritize the stickiness of the nodes accordingly.
